thread.title: A celebration of high school football
thread.title_full: A celebration of high school football

author: Eliav Appelbaum
title: A celebration of high school football
text:
Welcome to the Thunderdome. Oh, wait. That’s next year.
The Acorn All-Star football awards show continues—including anointing the Player of the Year—and we’ll put a bow on the season with the final, the definitive, the official Acorn Power Poll.
It’s go time.
CHAMPIONS FOR CHARACTER
Jackson Taylor
Alan Ko
The Thousand Oaks High students earned CIF-Southern Section Dr. Jim Staunton Champions for Character awards.
Taylor is a junior quarterback for the CIF semifinalist football team, Acorn All- Star and blue-chip college prospect. Ko, an Acorn All-Star and digital editor for the Lancer student newspaper, is the first high school student journalist to win the Champions for Character media award.
THE LONDON (TOP RECEIVER)
Cooper Cronquist
Moorpark senior wide receiver set school records with 159 career catches, 2,313 receiving yards in a career, and 254 receiving yards in one game against Oxnard on Oct. 18. Keep in mind, Moorpark is the same school that produced NFL receivers Drake London and Chad Hansen. Impressive.
INTERVIEW TEAM MVP
Nico Mastrippolito
Need a good quote? Oak Park senior wide receiver Nico Mastrippolito is the man. He is honest, articulate, smart, thoughtful and funny, and I always learn something new during our conversations.
If award-winning broadcaster Chris Myers (who lives in the area) interviewed Mastrippolito, that would be TV gold. Mastrippolito, a contender for top receiver, finished with 62 receptions for 1,101 yards and 13 touchdowns, and he added 16 tackles and two interceptions on defense.
COMEBACK PLAYER OF THE YEAR
Tagg Harrison
Harrison threw zero touchdown passes for Westlake last season.
This year, his first in a Simi Valley uniform, he had 2,835 passing yards and 22 touchdown strikes with five rushing scores. He led the Pioneers to a CIF championship game and a school-record 12 wins.
Harrison is humble, hardworking, smart, talented and resilient. He got knocked down—but he got up, dusted the dirt off his shoulder pads and went to work on the best comeback of 2024.
ROOKIE OF THE YEAR
Micah Hannah
Simi Valley freshman cornerback started for the CIF finalists. Hannah finished with 57 tackles, 16 pass deflections, one interception and one receiving touchdown. The 4.0 GPA student, the son of former NFL wide receiver Travis Hannah of the Houston Oilers, has college offers from the Arizona Wildcats and Texas A&M Aggies.
THE OCTOBOSS
Sam Kijner, Calabasas
Kijner is a bad man. And that’s a good thing. Calabasas senior linebacker led Coyotes with 93 tackles in award named after the guy who rides a flying motorcycle in “Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga.”
THE DANGERBIRD (TOP DEFENSIVE LINEMAN)
Isaac Thomas
Oak Park senior defensive lineman scored one of the biggest defensive touchdowns in school history in a memorable playoff win against Camarillo. Thomas, one of the best two-way linemen in program history, led Dangerbird Defense with 120 tackles and 12 sacks.
SNOT OTTER MVP
George Hastings
Some background: The Snot Otter is my nickname. I figure, if Kobe Bryant can give himself a goofy nickname like Black Mamba, I can, too.
Hastings, an Agoura sophomore, makes plays everywhere at quarterback, linebacker, running back, safety and tight end. He led the Chargers with 130 tackles, two interceptions, two forced fumbles and one blocked punt, and he scored seven touchdowns.
The 4.2 GPA scholar athlete also plays baseball—but he is the area’s most versatile football player.
GREEN HELMET / GREEN MONSTER AWARD
Cory McEnroe
Thousand Oaks senior linebacker/human sledgehammer led all Acorn country players with 172 tackles this season.
McEnroe played a pivotal role along the offensive line as a blocking tight end for Acorn All-Star running back Justin Lewis, who gleaned 1,306 yards and 15 touchdowns on the ground. McEnroe added 13 receptions for 172 yards and five total touchdowns for the Lancers, who reached the CIF playoff semifinals for the second straight year.
McEnroe is one of the best defensive players in Thousand Oaks history. He reminds me of Denver Broncos linebacker Alex Singleton, a Walter Payton Man of the Year nominee and a T.O. legend.
MOST IMPROVED PLAYER
Tillman Lovett
Oak Park senior quarterback was thrown into the fire in his first varsity start last year, the Kanan Bowl against Agoura, and he struggled.
He bounced back, big time.
The Eagle, the son of Los Angeles Rams director of strength and conditioning Justin Lovett, is the Most Improved Player of the Year. Tillman Lovett threw for 2,474 yards and 31 touchdowns while leading the Dangerbirds to the CIF playoff quarterfinals. Outside the Snot Otter’s Fortress of Verisimilitude, Lovett was under the proverbial radar all year.
OFFENSIVE PLAYER OF THE YEAR
Ethan LaSecla
The senior quarterback put up Tecmo Bowl numbers for Grace of Simi Valley, the Citrus Coast League champion.
LaSecla, a 3.98 GPA student, nearly had a 2,000-2,000 season: He had 2,253 yards and 23 touchdowns in the air, and he added 1,853 yards and 30 touchdowns on the ground. He has also played lacrosse, soccer and baseball at Grace.
The Lancer’s domination after starting high school in 8-man football is an extraordinary feat.
DEFENSIVE PLAYER OF THE YEAR
Drew Cofield
Cofield, a senior cornerback/receiver, made the biggest defensive play in the biggest game of the season for Newbury Park in the CIF-Southern Section Division 2 championship at Murrieta Valley. Cofield’s forced fumble at the goal-line was the play of the year, and it was the catalyst in a 31-28 win for the Panthers’ first section title since 1993.
The scholar athlete and UC Davis commit finished with 53 tackles and one interception, but Cofield’s impact goes beyond stats for the Black Cat Attack, the best defensive unit in the area.
Between Cofield, Christian Knoos of Oaks Christian (Linebacker of the Year), and Cory McEnroe of Thousand Oaks (Green Helmet/Green Monster Award), UC Davis snared the three best defensive players in Ventura County.
COACH OF THE YEAR
Joe Smigiel
The Panthers have talent, of course, but they don’t win a ring without Smigiel and his staff dialing up winning plays.
It wasn’t easy. The third-year head coach purged the roster of malcontents in his first training camp. In 2023, the defense was a work in progress and the offense stalled periodically, but the Black Cat Attack still reached a section final. The Panthers put it all together this season.
I tip my Seattle SuperSonics hat to Smigiel, the Coach of the Year.
ACORN NEWSPAPERS PLAYER OF THE YEAR
& WAYNE COOK QUARTERBACK OF THE YEAR
Brady Smigiel
Smigiel is a generational football player who has changed the sports landscape in Acorn country. That is not hyperbole.
The Newbury Park junior quarterback broke every significant county passing record last year, and he evolved into an even better player this season. The son of the Coach of the Year dialed up 3,521 passing yards with 49 touchdowns and only three interceptions. The future NFL player added 435 rushing yards and a team-high 11 scores on the ground. Brady Smigiel, a five-star field general with a big arm and a bigger brain, propelled the Panthers to their first CIF title in 31 years.
Teammate Shane “The Unicorn” Rosenthal earned Acorn Newspapers Player of the Year last fall. Smigiel wears the crown now, too.
Say it loud: Brady Smigiel is the best quarterback in Ventura County history. He has absolutely nothing left to prove in high school.
TEAM OF THE YEAR
NEWBURY PARK PANTHERS
The show goes on.

SNOT OTTER ALL-STARS*
• Gavin Gray, Agoura
• Lawson Grace, Westlake
• Axel Eason, Oaks Christian
• Evan Fanner, Oaks Christian
• Weston Schwesinger, Oaks Christian
*Players who endured injuries/time off field but still deserve Acorn All-Star nods
FINAL ACORN POWER POLL
1. NEWBURY PARK (14-1)
2. SIMI VALLEY (12-2)
3. THOUSAND OAKS (8-5)
4. MOORPARK (8-3)
5. AGOURA (9-2)
6. OAK PARK (8-4)
7. CALABASAS (6-5)
8. RIO MESA (7-5)
9. CAMARILLO (2-9)
10. ROYAL (2-8)
11. WESTLAKE (0-10)
That’s all, folks. See you next year.
